STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 24, 2025
Jennifer Stevens
Samaritas Mid-MI
729 W. Michigan Ave.
Jackson, MI, 49201-1920
Re: License #: CB380201255
Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
6/20/25. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least
annually and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
One of three foster home files did not have documentation that the agreement was
reviewed in 2024.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
One of two special evaluations did not have documentation that a copy of the report
was provided to the foster parent.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that the foster
parent has a right to have his or her written response
included as an attachment to the report required by
subrule (5) of this rule.
2

One of two special evaluations did not have documentation to indicate the foster
parent was notified they could provide a written response to the report.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(2) An agency shall inform foster parents of all the
following before they are questioned or interviewed
regarding a special evaluation:
(c) That the foster parents may involve a person of their
choice in any interviews with them involving the special
evaluation if the involvement does not impede the timely
completion of the evaluation.
One of two special evaluations did not have documentation that the foster parent
was notified they could have someone present when interviewed.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who
have children placed in the home must be notified there
is a corrective action plan and what is required of the
foster parent in that plan.
One of two special evaluations did not have documentation that the foster care
worker was informed of the corrective action plan for the foster home.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(2) For an emergency placement, if any of the
information specified in subrule (1)(a) to (h) of this rule is
not available at the time of placement, then the agency
shall provide information to the foster parent within 7
calendar days of the placement.
One of three foster care files did not have documentation that the required
information was provided to the foster parents within 7 days of placement.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and
the foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying
out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review
the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
3

parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the information
in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child's family is
confidential.
One of three foster care files did not have parent signatures on the February 2025
treatment plan to indicate the plan was reviewed with and provided to the parents.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's
placement at least once every month.
One of three foster care files did not have a monthly home visit with the child
documented for June 2024.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Special Evaluations- The agency was advised to document in the report, the
reason why any household member was not interviewed as part of the
investigation.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Special Evaluations- During the review it was noted that staff checked “yes” in
CWLM to the questions about verbal summaries provided to foster parents
and foster parent informed of allegations. However, when the report was
generated, the document indicated “no”. The agency was advised to monitor
this with future reports and call Help Desk to report any further issues.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with the CAP is as follows:
4

The agency’s renewal evaluation was completed on 6/11/2024, with a CAP
approved on 7/25/24. The CAP addressed violations regarding reevaluation
recommendations, borrowed home procedures, and special evaluation interviews.
The agency reported successful implementation of the CAP. There were no repeat
violations found during the current review.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) Assessment dated 5/29/25 was reviewed and
discussed. The CA reported that during this review period, the agency went
through a restructuring. This included transition of some staff to different positions
or locations and some layoffs. The CA indicated these changes impacted
timeliness of some work. However, the agency maintained high key-performance
indicator (KPI) percentages. The CA reported that in addition to the challenges of
restructuring and staff changes, the agency also had systemic struggles with
timely medical and dental exams in their area, due to limited provider ability. The
CA indicated that due to the low number of cases, just one late exam could deeply
impact their KPI percentage. The CA stated that another area of opportunity is
service plan approval timeliness. Due to the shift in positions and supervisors,
report revisions were delayed at times, leading to limited time for the supervisor to
approve the report.
The CA stated the agency was able to successfully implement the CAP from the
2024 review through increased tracking, use of calendar reminders, use of
protected time for staff, and thorough training with staff. The agency also moved to
a new quality process called IMPACT. It is anticipated this process will improve
review of data and implementation of processes. Regarding disrupted and
unplanned moves, the CA reported one placement that changed unexpectedly
The youth had extremely escalated behaviors, including threats to harm the foster
parents. The youth was taken to the hospital for evaluation, then placed with fictive
kin.
Financial Overview
The agency provided the 2025 budget and 2023 financial audit. The 2024 financial
audit is in progress. No financial concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed onsite. Both staff were caseworkers; one had been
with the agency for four years, and the other for one year. Both staff
acknowledged some challenges with the reconfiguration of the agency. Staff
indicated having a new supervisor was an adjustment, but the transition went well.
They described the supervisor as always available, supportive, knowledgeable,
and able to get timely answers to any questions. Staff reported there had been
some uncertainty initially with the agency changes. However, they felt that things
were still going well, and they did not have any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
5

The agency continues to be located in the same building as the 2024 review. The
office is in a large building in downtown Jackson. There is plenty of office and
meeting space for staff. There is visitation space available for families. The agency
had secure, locked, storage for confidential documents.
VII. AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and a corrective action plan is required.
_ _____________June 24, 2025________________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 24, 2025
